label: Letter from Major General Nathanael Greene addressed to Arthur Campbell
description: Letter from Major General Nathanael Greene addressed to Arthur Campbell regarding the ongoing hostilities in the states of North Carolina and Virginia. Greene is advising Campbell on how to best achieve peace with the Cherokee and Chiccasaw Native American tribes.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Letter from Major General Nathanael Greene addressed to Arthur Campbell regarding the ongoing hostilities in the states of North Carolina and Virginia. Greene is advising Campbell on how to best achieve peace with the Cherokee and Chiccasaw Native American tribes.

metadata.label: Access Note
metadata.value: For more information contact The Charleston Museum, 360 Meeting Street, Charleston, SC 29403.

metadata.label: Digitization Specifications
metadata.value: 600 ppi, 24-bit depth, color, Epson Expression 10000XL, Archival Masters are tiffs.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
[Major General Nathanael Greene addressed to Arthur Campbell 
February 26, 1781
[RvW, Box 1 Folder 6; MSS. â€“ D.S.]]

By the Honourable Nathanael Greene
Esquire, Major General in the Service of
the United States, and Commanding 
Officer of the Southern Department.
To William Christian, William
Preston, Arther [sic] Campbell, and Joseph
Martin of the State of Virginia, and 
Robert Severe [Sevier], Evan Shelby, Joseph
Williams, and John Severe [Sevier] of the State
of North Carolina.
Whereas there have arose Hosti-
-lities between the subjects of the United States,
Situated on the Western Frontiers of Virginia
[and] North Carolina, and the Nations or Tribes
of Indians called the Cherokees, [and] Chiccasaws [sic],
from a mutual apprehension of encroachments
on the lands of each other. And it being
represented to me that a Mutual desire hath
taken place between the contending parties,
to treat on an adjustment of their respective
limits, for an exchange of prisoners, of a 
Suspension of Hostilities, or conclusion of a
peace, which treats those concerned, Subjects of
the United States, conceive they are not at
present authorised [sic] to enter into. And
it being essentially interesting to the Service
of the Southern Department, that a Speedy
close be put to the said hostilities and
that harmony between the Contending parties
be restored, I do therefore, as Commanding
Officer of the Southern department, hereby
nominate and appoint you, the said William
Christian
[End Page 1]
Christian, William Preston, Arther Campbel [sic], Joseph
Martin, Robert Severe, Evan Shelby, Joseph 
Williams, [and] John Severe Esquires, or any five
of you, Commissioners on the part of the United
States, to meet such Commissioners, as the
said Tribes or Nations of Indians shall appoint
on their part, at such time [and] place at such
place within the disputed ground as shall
be agreed on for the purpose of treating, or
the adjustment of the respective limits of each
party, negotiating an exchange of prisoners, 
a suspension of Hostilities conclusion of a
peace, or any thing else for the establishment
of harmony [and] good understanding between
the contending parties, as to you may seem
proper, Subject to the conformation of
Congress.  in adjusting the limits of the
respective parties you are to be governed
by the Laws of the said two States of Virginia
[and] North Carolina within their respective
Boundiries [sic]. You are to exchange such
Mutual pledges for securing an Observance
of the Treaties concluded on, as may be
thought necessary, and you are hereby
charged to call on the Lieutenants or Comman-
-ding Officers of the Adjacent Counties within
the said two States for force [and] assistance
to prevent any future encroachments of the
Subjects of the United States on the lands
of the said Tribes or Nations of Indians.
And as it will contribute much to 
remove the jealousies now entertained by 
thou
[End Page 2]
thou Tribes of Indians, and the laying 
a foundation for the establishment of 
harmony [and] a good a good Understanding 
Between the subjects of the United 
States [and] them, to afford the said Tribes 
of Indians every mark of our good 
dispositions towards them, you will 
call on them to appoint certain 
persons from amongst themselves, 
to go to Congress for Obtaining such 
enlargements, or confirmations of their
Treaties as may appear to them 
requisite.
This Commission is to continue 
in force till revoked, by the Comman[ding] 
Officer of the Southern department, 
The Commander in Chief of the Ame-
-rican Army, or The Honrble [sic] the 
Congress of the United States.
Given Under my hand in 
Camp in Caswell County North 
Carolina this twenty sixth day 
of February one thousand seven 
Hundred [and] Eighty one
Nath [Nathanael] Greene
[End Page 3]
[Addressed:]
To Arthur Campbell
[?]     Feb: 26th 1781
[End Page 4]
